title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.6.19-20 | 15-11-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: I desire to see again that transcendental form of the Lord in the heart, but despite my attempts to concentrate upon the heart, with eagerness to view the form again.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Narada Muni's desire to see the Lord again after a brief vision, and his subsequent dissatisfaction when he couldn't.

segments.key_quote: There is no mechanical process to see the Lord, and it completely depends upon the causeless mercy of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that seeing the Lord is not a mechanical process based on karma, but depends entirely on the Lord's causeless mercy, using the analogy of the sun rising.

segments.key_quote: One is our own sincere efforts according to the scriptural direction, according to the instructions of the bona fide spiritual master, according to the process, authorized process that has to be there. But this alone is not enough.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that while seeing the Lord depends on His mercy, sincere effort and following the authorized process are also necessary, and recounts Narada Muni's failed second attempt.

segments.key_quote: He can simply be bound up by the tie of unalloyed devotion... It is love that can bind the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that pure, unalloyed devotion is what pleases and binds the Lord, illustrating this with the story of Mother Yashoda trying to tie Krishna.

segments.key_quote: The Lord is not visible or perceivable by our material senses... He may be seen out of his own accord when he gives darshan, when he gives vision to us.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Lord's spiritual form cannot be perceived by material senses, but He can give darshan out of His causeless mercy, though people may misunderstand His form.

segments.key_quote: Seeing my attempts in that lonely place, the personality of Godhead who is transcendental to all mundane description spoke to me with gravity and pleasing words just to mitigate my grief.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 20th verse, explaining that the Lord spoke to Narada to mitigate his grief, and discusses how the Lord's words are beyond mundane understanding, yet accessible by His mercy.

segments.key_quote: A devotee in love feels always the pangs of separation, and is therefore always enwrapped in transcendental ecstasy.
segments.summary: The speaker clarifies that even Narada Muni, despite his advancement, was not fully purified, and discusses the devotee's feelings of separation and the value of hearing the Lord, ending with a thank you and Hare Krishna.
